conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the motion of the rod and the capacitor, considering the magnetic fields and the forces involved. The key is to determine the charge on the capacitor and the polarity of the charges on the plates M and N.

The switch S is initially connected to terminal 1, the capacitor is fully charged, the rod ab is ejected out of the magnetic field, and the center of mass of the frame abcd rises by 0.2 m on the inclined track.
The magnetic field strength in the left half of the ring is \( B_1 = 1 \, \text{T} \), and the magnetic field strength in the right half of the ring is \( B_2 = 1 \, \text{T} \).
The angular displacement of the rods is calculated as \(\theta = \omega \times t = 600 \times 0.01 = 6 \, \text{rad}\).
The magnetic force on the rod is given by \( F = B_1 l_1 \sin(\theta) \), and substituting values, \( F = 1 \times 0.25 \times \sin(6) \).
The charge \( Q \) on the capacitor is calculated using \( Q = CV \), where \( C = 0.09 \, \text{F} \) and \( V = 600 \). Substituting values, \( Q = 0.09 \times 600 = 54 \, \text{C} \).
The polarity of the charges is determined based on the upward movement of the center of mass of the frame abcd, indicating that plate M is positively charged.
The final answer is that the charge \( Q \) on the capacitor is 54 C, and plate M is positively charged.
